channel.name: Field division on big number, strange result

messages.content:
Hello,
I use o1js 1.3.0 and I got a strange result when I tried to divide 2 fields :

```
    let amount2: Field = Field(49750000000000000000000n).div(Field(14975000000000n));
    console.log("amountOut", amount2.toString());                                                                                                                                                                                      
    amountOut 11743521571230315312156823604804324544402709056947911943200311275023425933509         
```
I don't know why the number is big like this (maybe it handles decimals like this), I need to convert the result in Uint64
field division isnt uint division afaik cc @gregor
exactly! read the manual 😄
so, `Field(1).div(2)` is the same as `Field(2).inv()`: a number that, when multiplied with 2, overflows the field in such a way as to exactly give 1
how can I perform my operation then?
maybe we need a Uint128 with mathematical operation support
Do you need it on variables in your circuit, or just on constants?
Also I saw I can have similar problème with square method, I use it too in other calculation (Uint64 doesn't have a square method)
Squaring is just multiplying the same number though

Do you only need to check how big the value is? Then you could alternatively check 
numerator < denominator * maxuint
I just need to check is not overriding Uint64 because is for transfer token
the complete method

@Youtpout moving this into `Provable.asProver()` is invalid. it's not part of the proof and the constraints added are just constraints on the constant 0.
But I think you're close! what you really want to do is return `amountOutField` from `Provable.witness(Field, () => ...)`
oh provable witness will prove the calculation ?
no! but it will return a variable which you can then constrain
right now, you're just "constraining" the 0 constant
finaly just add 1 is not suffisient the deviation can be bigger
you could also just look at the division method for `UInt64` and do the same but allowing a larger range

the idea is, to do a division that rounds down, you compute a quotient q and remainder r such that
```
numerator == q*denominator + r
```
and
```
r < denominator
```
then, q is your division result.

you also have to range-check q so that the multiplication `q*denominator` cannot overflow
q and r are witnessed
can be a good idea in a second time, I will try to publish a beta, and after correct these problems
I just hope you don't use your "trick" above even in the beta 😛
@Youtpout in OCaml there are overflow checking methods
My problem isn't overflow, it's doing a division with an integer result.
I would think this is enough since you can take quotient and remainder as witness and check it manually, checking for overflow
